page.title: 07Intensive farming in Bourtie
page.content: There are two farmers with over 1000 acres in Bourtie, but mos of the farms run by the older generation are around the 200 acre size. Many farmers with larger vistas, i.e. those below the 500 feet level, have in the last five yars removed the boundaries of drystane dykes (dry stone walls) where the land has allowed. But most of the smaller farmers have kept the dykes because they provide shelter and show points of reference which can be used to trace old water and drainage courses. Where the larger-acreage farmers have benefitted inopening up land for heavier equipment to cultivate or harvest, they have lost in damaged drains and natural water supplies. One farmer uprooted all they dykes inside a 100 acre stretch; then had to import mechanical diggers to provide the hillside with drainage.
